captions.text:
"The Universe," informally, means "everything
there is" - mountains and oceans and the moon

and hot nuclear balls of hydrogen and a whole
lot more.

But if the Universe is "everything", does
that mean it includes the things that we don't

know that we don't know exist? Or even the
things that we believe exist but haven't yet

seen or observed? For example, is the future
a part of the universe?

In physics, we usually distinguish between
these two notions of universe as 1) the "observable

universe," which is everything whose existence
we've thus far been able to confirm or observe,

and 2) "The Universe" with a capital U, or,
"The Whole Universe," which is everything

that exists, has existed, or will exist, any
time, anywhere, regardless of whether or not
we're aware of it yet (or ever will be).

Of course, the main reason for this distinction
is so that we can talk scientifically about

parts of the universe we haven't yet been
able to observe, and the two biggest reasons

we might not have been able to observe a piece
of the universe yet are either it's in the

future or it's so far away that light from
it hasn't had time to reach us - yet. To explain:

as far as we know, the universe had a beginning
and is now around 13.8 billion years old.

Light takes time to travel through space,
so anywhere too far away from us just isn't

visible yet in the same way that thunder from
a distant lightning strike isn't audible - until

you wait long enough. If you were blind, the
thunder would be the first sign you have of

the storm's existence, though once you hear
it, you can infer that the storm must have
existed all along.

So within the observable universe, what do
we know "exists"? Pretty much just three things:

spacetime, particles, and the physical laws
that describe how spacetime and those particles

interact to give rise to gravity and matter
and forces and everything else. It's open

for debate whether or not mathematics is a
part of the universe or if it exists "outside"

the universe in some sort of mathematical
heavens - but if you think that mathematics

exists and if The Universe is everything that
exists, then, well... I'll leave that up to
you.

There's one other thing, though - you may
have heard of parallel universes, or "Multiverses,"

an idea proposed by researchers or sci-fi
fanatics that perhaps what we think of as

The Universe is actually just a small piece
of a larger thing which is really "everything

there is"... but that's anotherverse in the
story.

comments.author: Bilal Khan

comments.text:
Depends on how you define "Universe". I'm not going to get all 
philosophical here, but if we describe the Universe as OUR Universe (i.e. 
expanding space-time with energy in it), then beyond that is... nothing.

And by nothing I DON't mean a vacuum, as a vacuum is defined as an empty 
region of space time. By "nothing", I mean no space-time.

Of course, even in "nothing" you can still theoretically have energy and 
the laws of physics, so maybe there's no such thing as nothing?! It's very 
strange.

comments.author: carey g. butler

comments.text:
+carey g. butler
*Have you investigated the possibility that light is not the only method of 
propagation in our Universe?*
By far, propagation of mass, energy, probability, effects from events and 
of course space-time itself propagates from at least it's flexibility and 
likely inflation. The evidence though is that the fastest propagation is 
achieved through light. The closest concept that could change that (as far 
as I know) is Variable Speed of Light, but VSL does not have corroborating 
evidence nor does it predict observations as we know them today.

*Are you sure our Universe originated with a Big Bang?*
I'm not a cosmologist but I do understand there are others such as steady 
state, oscillating, De Sitter,  unending inflation with isolated pockets of 
mass/energy we call universes, some strange forms of digital. Just to name 
a few.
The best evidence we have indicates that inflation is the most accurate 
understanding we have that fits the observed evidence. Now if we uncover 
evidence that contradicts inflation, than another needs to be developed. 
Actually if I remember correctly inflation is a correction of the original 
big bang when CMB did not match up, to me that is the flexibility of 
science in action.

*It seems you've bought into the mainstream pretty much though.*
That's a fairly loaded statement, the best way to reply is that for things 
I'm not an expert at I follow the evidence of the experts. But I don't do 
so blindly, since I have enough understanding to be able to 
non-scientifically critique and evaluate some concepts.
For example, Dark Matter has been given properties which lead to 
investigating WIMPS. Well after much research and experiments to detect, 
not a single conclusive piece of evidence has come forth. I won't write any 
scientific papers but from my perspective WIMPS is a bad hypothesis and 
should be discarded.
When *mainstream science* provides the preponderance of evidence such as GR 
and the speed of light and their work provides results like GR, Newtonian 
Physics, QM, then yes I trust the accuracy of mainstream science.
Can I go beyond that so as not to be dogmatic? By Far! One of my favorite 
topics is time travel. Since there is no credible evidence of time travel 
(to the past), it really falls into *Not even wrong* as science so far. But 
I particularly enjoy understand and thinking of the implications of Novikov 
Self-Consistency Principle. The copy concepts I discussed in MWI previously 
was from discussing time travel and branching parallel universes with a 
science fiction author.
comments.author: Ergodic Mage

comments.text:
+Ergodic Mage There's so much there to comment on, I don't know where to 
start!

Have you investigated the possibility that light is not the only method of 
propagation in our Universe? Are you sure our Universe originated with a

Those are just a few of many of your assertions that need clarification. It 
seems you've bought into the mainstream pretty much though. I've been 
involved with science for over 30 years, so I've had a chance to branch out 
a bit. What about you?
comments.author: carey g. butler

comments.text:
Minute Physics has a tendency to gloss over concepts, but it's purpose 
isn't to delve too deep.
I don't like how he presents mathematics as possibly being outside or 
inside the universe. But I think the concept attempted in a simplified 
manner is *does the universe obey mathematics or is mathematics a human 
tool invented to understand what we observe?*
I find that to be a very important question to answer. If the universe 
obeys mathematics then it implies a logical structuring which opens a wide 
range of philosophical concepts.
If mathematics is just a human tool to understand what we observe (my 
personal perspective) then there is no such underlying structure or implied 
logic. The universe just is what it is and we have to figure it out piece 
by piece.

I also don't like how he presents the 3 things that exist, though it's 
simplified to easily identify classical, relativity and quantum mechanics.
Personally (and not necessarily scientifically) I'd classify the 3 things 
we know exists as:
1. Energy, he presents it as particles, but particles came from the energy 
of the big bang.
2. Events that make up measurable interactions and given ability by energy. 
Without events nothing happens leading to a zero sum universe.
3. Container for all of the events and energy which allows them. We call 
this space-time from relativity.
So Energy is important in two ways, the formation of matter in the early 
universe so that Events interact with mass, and to power those events.
The Events is what we observe directly. We don't observe space-time 
directly but we observe interactions between masses and apply our tool of 
GR and we understand that demonstrates gravity and it's affect on 
space-time.
The Container (space-time) is to distinguish each event as unique, so we 
can say this event and that event without confusion. This container is also 
flexible which allows interaction of events over distances and times, 
leading to the concept of cause and effect.

Now our minds are of course part of the universe and as such interact and 
shape events. But the interactions and effects are fairly local, they do 
populate through the universe but at the speed of light.
So my very first interaction when born effects the universe in a small way, 
but the effects of the that thought or action (crying) has only reached out 
48 light years.

Outside of that range the universe doesn't even know that I exist as a 
person. 25,000 light years away, the universe doesn't even know that 
civilized humans exist, that means we haven't even completely effected our 
galaxy as yet.
So what we observe as immediate or quick impact of our thoughts and actions 
are only a local observation and diminishes the further out from us.
So our thoughts matter a great deal to us but all together the universe 
probably doesn't even register them beyond a minuscule effect.

comments.text:
"Universe" is an interpretable term. Myself, I'm used to seeing it as the 
container in which everything related to our space and time exists. As in, 
an enormous multi-dimensional object where space is "drawn" / modeled in 
the first 3 dimensions, time in the 4th, possibilities / time lines as the 
5th, and anything beyond. We living beings perceive the first 3 directly, 
from a snapshot of the 4th across which we go in one direction (past to 
future), while taking choices by changing our body's probability in the 5th.

The multiverse theory does add a lot to this however. By saying that 
somewhere even higher, an unimaginable number of such universes branch off, 
each with different mathematical rules for particles. A word other than 
"universe" might be more comfortable for us in describing it at this stage.﻿

comments.text:
This is a very naive and confused presentation: you failed to mention that 
a fundamental possible reason for not being able to observe something is 
that the something is not detectable via our human senses, (regardless of 
whether it's in our universe or some other universe). There may be an 
infinite number of types of objects which simply do not interact with types 
of matter, energy, and forces which we can detect and so will never be 
detectable.

And not being able to observe something because "it's in the future"??? 
Surely the future is just referring to predictions about what may happen in 
the future. Things can't exist in the future so saying that we can't 
observe something because it's in the future is nonsense.

Thus, for the sake of good education I think you would be wise to improve 
this video, Henry.﻿
comments.author: Jamie Anderson

comments.text:
+MrTrent117 You've missed the point entirely. There may be things we will 
never be able to detect because they don't interact with the types of 
things we can detect, like x-rays. X-rays have measurable energy and 
momentum and we ONLY know they exist because they interact with measuring 
instruments we can detect with our senses, (or more indirectly they may 
give us cancer, the symptoms of which we can only detect with our senses).

comments.author: Sorin Cristian

comments.text:
@Frijole(for some reason youtube is not allowing me to reply to you right 
now)

The age of the universe is estimated to be 13.8 billion years. While it is 
commonly understood that nothing can accelerate to velocities equal to or 
greater than that of light, it is a common misconception that the radius of 
the observable universe must therefore amount to only 13.8 billion 
light-years. This reasoning would only make sense if the flat, static 
Minkowski spacetime conception under special relativity were correct. In 
the real universe, spacetime is curved in a way that corresponds to the 
expansion of space, as evidenced by Hubble's law. Distances obtained as the 
speed of light multiplied by a cosmological time interval have no direct 
physical significance.﻿

comments.text:
by defining the word Universe to include all that exists, it disallows the 
common logical fallacy that is used to explain the fact of existence with

the god. by taking the main concept of the question (why do things exist at 
all instead of nothing existing) and including god within the question, you 
realize that god cannot answer the question. there is no special privilege 
that god gets to ignore the question altogether.

comments.text:
Math IS fundamentally abstract. There are no "laws of math", and there is 
no embodiment of mathematics that could be changed. What people fail to 
realize is that math doesn't exist the way the universe does. Math "exists" 
in the sense that "shape" exists, or existence itself exists, for which 
there is no defined "system". Would you say that in another universe, 
existence itself doesn't exist? That merely wouldn't fit the definition of 
"existence". There is one way to exist, and one way to count.

you translate it to intelligible language or not. Like everything else. A 
giraffe couldn't care less if humans invented a word to make it an 
intelligible concept. The mathematical patterns we identify and translate 
into concepts we can understand still exists, regardless our comprehension.

comments.text:
I think what people mean is that the RULES of mathematics are just as much 
a property of the universe as the laws of physics. I'm not saying it is or 
it isn't, but clearly this age old debate would have solved years ago had 
people actually believe that you could find a number 2 lying on the ground.

comments.text:
Humans didn't invent mathematics, we may have invented different branches 
of mathematics which take the form of an approach to solve problems. 
Mathematics arises off of basic axioms in logic. You can't invent a theorem 
like the relationship between a circle and its diameter or the radius and 
its area, thats discovering a relationship. A number 2 doesnt have to lay 
on the ground to exists. Its an abstract concept. But you have to deny the 
existence of the abstract to hold your view.

comments.text:
We observed the stars with telescopes and spectrometers. We noticed them 
moving away based on red shifting. We have background radiation leftover 
from the big bang. We calculate how long it takes for the particles to 
expand from one point outward and clump here and there to what we have 
today. Included in the calculations is the rate space-time is expanding. 
Etc.
comments.author: TonyTheAnything

comments.author: SUPARAINBOWYOSHI

comments.text:
Numbers may not exist in the universe without humans; however mathematics 
as a principle exists. Numbers are used to determine the scale between 
objects and forces, but as to how objects and forces interact with 
each-other is beyond our knowledge. A particle colliding with another 
particle follows the same rules (to an extent) every time, and those rules 
are based on maths that we don't understand. Basically, IMO maths is more 
than just a language because even without us, the universe operates.

comments.text:
The language of mathmatics is an arbitrary human conception, yes. We could 
have called two "phasn" if we wanted to. Be the concept that our word, two, 
describes obviously is a natural phenomenon, because objects and events are 
not perfectly unique. As in they can share some aspect with each other, 
like temporal simultaneity, or chemical composition, or physical 
appearance. Just because we arbitrarily choose the word to call it doesn't 
mean it's not a natural occurring thing.

physical process. In this theory the physics of quantum mechanics 
represents the physics of time. The wave particle duality of light is 
acting like the bits or zeros and ones of a computer forming a blank canvas

emergent property with the future coming into existence photon by photon 
relative to the position and actions of the atoms!
